stories.title: A new startup inception pattern is developing in Ukraine
Software aims to make your flight smoother–and help the planet
Long division: theory, methods and their comparison

stories.text:
I'm a first-time founder, and very introverted. After meeting 50 VCs, it comes as no surprise that we weren't able to raise money. My startup is post-product, and growing double-digit MoM (not consistently though).

I've concluded that in order for first-time founders to get funding, you need at least one of the following:

1. You have personal relationships with VCs, 2. Your startup is post product-market fit, i.e. >10% WoW growth, 3. You bootstrap all the way through by charging users early

If I was to start over again, I'd go with option 3. Squatted on zoom calls with VCs trying to pitch your vision, background, and MVP narrative in some exaggerated way isn't my cup of tea. I get tense. I shake. I find it appalling to ask for money. But, I know fundraising is a skill every founder must build, no matter how repulsive they find the process to be.

Would love thoughts from other startup founders.
